t: Proverbs 10
Proverbs of Solomon
The*p proverbs of Solomon: A*pn wise son brings joy to his father, but*ld a foolish son brings grief to his mother.
Ill-gotten*pn treasures have no lasting value, but*ld righteousness delivers from death.
The*pn Lord*s does not let the righteous go hungry, but*ld he thwarts the craving of the wicked.
Lazy*pn hands make for poverty, but*ld diligent hands bring wealth.
He*pn who gathers crops in summer is a prudent son, but*ld he who sleeps during harvest is a disgraceful son.
Blessings*pn crown the head of the righteous, but*ld violence overwhelms the mouth of the wicked.
The*pn name of the righteous is used in blessings, but*ld the name of the wicked will rot.
The*pn wise in heart accept commands, but*ld a chattering fool comes to ruin.
Whoever*pn walks in integrity walks securely, but*ld whoever takes crooked paths will be found out.
Whoever*pn winks maliciously causes grief, and*ld a chattering fool comes to ruin.
The*pn mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life, but*ld the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
Hatred*pn stirs up conflict, but*ld love covers over all wrongs.
Wisdom*pn is found on the lips of the discerning, but*ld a rod is for the back of one who has no sense.
The*pn wise store up knowledge, but*ld the mouth of a fool invites ruin.
The*pn wealth of the rich is their fortified city, but*ld poverty is the ruin of the poor.
The*pn wages of the righteous is life, but*ld the earnings of the wicked are sin and death.
Whoever*pn heeds discipline shows the way to life, but*ld whoever ignores correction leads others astray.
Whoever*pn conceals hatred with lying lips and*ld spreads slander is a fool.
Sin*pn is not ended by multiplying words, but*ld the prudent hold their tongues.
The*pn tongue of the righteous is choice silver, but*ld the heart of the wicked is of little value.
The*pn lips of the righteous nourish many, but*ld fools die for lack of sense.
The*pn blessing of the Lord*s brings wealth, without*ld painful toil for it.
A*pn fool finds pleasure in wicked schemes, but*ld a person of understanding delights in wisdom.
What*pn the wicked dread will overtake them; what*ld the righteous desire will be granted.
When*pn the storm has swept by, the wicked are gone, but*ld the righteous stand firm forever.
As*pn vinegar to the teeth and smoke to the eyes, so*ld are sluggards to those who send them.
The*pn fear of the Lord*s adds length to life, but*ld the years of the wicked are cut short.
The*pn prospect of the righteous is joy, but*ld the hopes of the wicked come to nothing.
The*pn way of the Lord*s is a refuge for the blameless, but*ld it is the ruin of those who do evil.
The*pn righteous will never be uprooted, but*ld the wicked will not remain in the land.
From*pn the mouth of the righteous comes the fruit of wisdom, but*ld a perverse tongue will be silenced.
The*pn lips of the righteous know what finds favor, but*ld the mouth of the wicked only what is perverse.
